question: But in theory it is admitted that an adult person in [MASK] of knowledge must not be refused it on the ground that he would be better or happier without it.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: It is a right that is as yet very imperfectly recognized in practice.
next_sentence: Parents and priests may forbid knowledge to those who accept their authority; and social taboo may be made effective by acts of legal persecution under cover of repressing blasphemy, obscenity, and sedition; but no government now openly forbids its subjects to pursue knowledge on the ground that knowledge is in itself a bad thing, or that it is possible for any of us to have too much of it.

question: What it will [MASK] mean for him is release from his present degrading and scientifically corrupting slavery to his patients.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: THE FUTURE OF PRIVATE PRACTICE  It must not be hastily concluded that this involves the extinction of the private practitioner.
next_sentence: As I have already shown the doctor who has to live by pleasing his patients in competition with everybody who has walked the hospitals, scraped through the examinations, and bought a brass plate, soon finds himself prescribing water to teetotallers and brandy or champagne jelly to drunkards; beefsteaks and stout in one house, and "uric acid free" vegetarian diet over the way; shut windows, big fires, and heavy overcoats to old Colonels, and open air and as much nakedness as is compatible with decency to young faddists, never once daring to say either "I don't know," or "I don't agree."

question: It is hardly to be expected that a man who does not hesitate to vivisect for the sake of science will hesitate to [MASK] about it afterwards to protect it from what he deems the ignorant sentimentality of the laity.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: And this brings us to an obvious but mostly overlooked weakness in the vivisector's position: that is, his inevitable forfeiture of all claim to have his word believed.
next_sentence: When the public conscience stirs uneasily and threatens suppression, there is never wanting some doctor of eminent position and high character who will sacrifice himself devotedly to the cause of science by coming forward to assure the public on his honor that all experiments on animals are completely painless; although he must know that the very experiments which first provoked the antivivisection movement by their atrocity were experiments to ascertain the physiological effects of the sensation of extreme pain (the much more interesting physiology of pleasure remains uninvestigated) and that all experiments in which sensation is a factor are voided by its suppression.

question: In the ranks of ordinary skilled labor many men are to be found who earn good wages and are never out of a job because they are strong, indefatigable, and skilful, and who therefore are bold in a high opinion of themselves; but they are selfish and [MASK], gluttonous and drunken, as their wives and children know to their cost.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Unsuccessful, unskilful men are often much more scrupulous than successful ones.
next_sentence: Not only do these talented energetic people retain their self-respect through shameful misconduct: they do not even lose the respect of others, because their talents benefit and interest everybody, whilst their vices affect only a few.

question: In short, the doctor [MASK] our help for the moment much more than we often need his.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Even the most eminent physicians, as such biographies as those of Paget show, are sometimes miserably, inhumanly poor until they are past their prime.
next_sentence: The ridicule of Moliere, the death of a well-informed and clever writer like the late Harold Frederic in the hands of Christian Scientists (a sort of sealing with his blood of the contemptuous disbelief in and dislike of doctors he had bitterly expressed in his books), the scathing and quite justifiable exposure of medical practice in the novel by Mr. Maarten Maartens entitled The New Religion: all these trouble the doctor very little, and are in any case well set off by the popularity of Sir Luke Fildes' famous picture, and by the verdicts in which juries from time to time express their conviction that the doctor can do no wrong.

question: Operations enable a surgeon to earn similar [MASK] in a couple of hours; and if the surgeon also keeps a nursing home, he may make considerable profits at the same time by running what is the most expensive kind of hotel.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: And every hypochondriacal rich lady or gentleman who can be persuaded that he or she is a lifelong invalid means anything from fifty to five hundred pounds a year for the doctor.
next_sentence: These gains are so great that they undo much of the moral advantage which the absence of grinding pecuniary anxiety gives the rich doctor over the poor one.

question: Scientific measures are too hard to understand, too costly, too clearly tending towards a rise in the rates and more public interference with the insanitary, because insufficiently [MASK], private house.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: But it is poor and wants to be protected cheaply.
next_sentence: What the public wants, therefore, is a cheap magic charm to prevent, and a cheap pill or potion to cure, all disease.

question: We do not go to the [MASK] table as we go to the theatre, to the picture gallery, to the concert room, to be entertained and delighted: we go to be tormented and maimed, lest a worse thing should befall us.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: The surgeon's art is exercised at its expense, not for its gratification.
next_sentence: It is of the most extreme importance to us that the experts on whose assurance we face this horror and suffer this mutilation should leave no interests but our own to think of; should judge our cases scientifically; and should feel about them kindly.

question: Now there is no calculation that an engineer can make as to the [MASK] of a girder under a strain, or an astronomer as to the recurrence of a comet, more certain than the calculation that under such circumstances we shall be dismembered unnecessarily in all directions by surgeons who believe the operations to be necessary solely because they want to perform them.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: My wife--my pretty ones--the leg may mortify--it is always safer to operate--he will be well in a fortnight--artificial legs are now so well made that they are really better than natural ones--evolution is towards motors and leglessness, etc., etc., etc."
next_sentence: The process metaphorically called bleeding the rich man is performed not only metaphorically but literally every day by surgeons who are quite as honest as most of us.

question: It is just so in the case of the [MASK] to knowledge.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: In countries where there is compulsory military service he may even have to throw away his individual life to save the life of the community.
next_sentence: It is a right that is as yet very imperfectly recognized in practice.

question: He who [MASK] the least scepticism as to this practice is at once suspected of being``an old-fashioned doctor ,"and dismissed to make room for a younger man.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Plenty of our most popular elderly doctors believe that cold tubs in the morning are unnatural, exhausting, and rheumatic; that fresh air is a fad and that everybody is the better for a glass or two of port wine every day; but they no longer dare say as much until they know exactly where they are; for many very desirable patients in country houses have lately been persuaded that their first duty is to get up at six in the morning and begin the day by taking a walk barefoot through the dewy grass.
next_sentence: In short, private medical practice is governed not by science but by supply and demand; and however scientific a treatment may be, it cannot hold its place in the market if there is no demand for it; nor can the grossest quackery be kept off the market if there is a demand for it.

question: They are not trained in the use of evidence, nor in biometrics, nor in the psychology of human credulity, nor in the incidence of economic [MASK].
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: PATIENT-MADE THERAPEUTICS  To all these blunders and ignorances doctors are no less subject than the rest of us.
next_sentence: Further, they must believe, on the whole, what their patients believe, just as they must wear the sort of hat their patients wear.

question: Assuming that doctors are normal men and not magicians (and it is [MASK] very hard to persuade people to admit so much and thereby destroy the romance of doctoring) we may guess that the medical profession, like the other professions, consists of a small percentage of highly gifted persons at one end, and a small percentage of altogether disastrous duffers at the other.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Under such conditions no statistics as to the graduation of professional ability among doctors are available.
next_sentence: Between these extremes comes the main body of doctors (also, of course, with a weak and a strong end) who can be trusted to work under regulations with more or less aid from above according to the gravity of the case.

question: But the scare of infection, though it sets even doctors talking as if the only really scientific thing to do with a fever patient is to throw him into the nearest ditch and pump [MASK] acid on him from a safe distance until he is ready to be cremated on the spot, has led to much greater care and cleanliness.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: We now know that the medieval horror of leprosy was out of all proportion to the danger of infection, and was accompanied by apparent blindness to the infectiousness of smallpox, which has since been worked up by our disease terrorists into the position formerly held by leprosy.
next_sentence: And the net result has been a series of victories over disease.

question: It is true, there are grave scandals in the public medical [MASK].
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: He has a safe, dignified, responsible, independent position based wholly on the public health; whereas the private practitioner has a precarious, shabby-genteel, irresponsible, servile position, based wholly on the prevalence of illness.
next_sentence: The public doctor may be also a private practitioner eking out his earnings by giving a little time to public work for a mean payment.

question: The doctor never hesitates to claim [MASK] omniscience, nor to clamor for laws to punish any scepticism on the part of laymen.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: To-day all this is changed.
next_sentence: A modern doctor thinks nothing of signing the death certificate of one of his own diphtheria patients, and then going into the witness box and swearing a peculiar into prison for six months by assuring the jury, on oath, that if the prisoner's child, dead of diphtheria, had been placed under his treatment instead of that of St. James, it would not have lived.

question: No doubt the higher the life we secure to the individual by wise social organization, the greater his value is to the community, and the more pains we shall take to pull him through any [MASK] danger or disablement.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: The theory that every individual alive is of infinite value is legislatively impracticable.
next_sentence: But the man who costs more than he is worth is doomed by sound hygiene as inexorably as by sound economics.

question: In every generation fools and blackguards have made this claim; and honest and [MASK] men, led by the strongest contemporary minds, have repudiated it and exposed its crude rascality.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: For here we look in vain for either an economic or a sentimental motive.
next_sentence: From Shakespear and Dr. Johnson to Ruskin and Mark Twain, the natural abhorrence of sane mankind for the vivisector's cruelty, and the contempt of able thinkers for his imbecile casuistry, have been expressed by the most popular spokesmen of humanity.

question: He is made of the same [MASK] as the ignorant, shallow, credulous, half-miseducated, pecuniarily anxious people who call him in when they have tried in vain every bottle and every pill the advertizing druggist can persuade them to buy.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: It is not in his capacity of healer and man of science that the doctor vivisects or defends vivisection, but in his entirely vulgar lay capacity.
next_sentence: The real remedy for vivisection is the remedy for all the mischief that the medical profession and all the other professions are doing: namely, more knowledge.

question: The results are sometimes no worse than the ordinary results of dirt [MASK] into cuts; but neither the doctor nor the patient is quite satisfied unless the inoculation``takes"; that is, unless it produces perceptible illness and disablement.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors

question: These two cases of ordinary vaccination and [MASK] are typical of all the rest.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: But Hahnemann and his followers were frantically persecuted for a century by generations of apothecary-doctors whose incomes depended on the quantity of drugs they could induce their patients to swallow.
next_sentence: Just as the object of a trade union under existing conditions must finally be, not to improve the technical quality of the work done by its members, but to secure a living wage for them, so the object of the medical profession today is to secure an income for the private doctor; and to this consideration all concern for science and public health must give way when the two come into conflict.

question: The same boundless credulity which the public exhibit as to a doctor's power of diagnosis was shown by the [MASK] themselves as to the analytic microbe hunters.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: When the bacillus was found, as it frequently was, in persons who were not suffering from the disease, the theory was saved by simply calling the bacillus an impostor, or pseudobacillus.
next_sentence: These witch finders would give you a certificate of the ultimate constitution of anything from a sample of the water from your well to a scrap of your lungs, for seven-and-sixpense.

question: Just so do we [MASK] a crowd of petty vivisectionists daily committing atrocities and stupidities, because it is the custom to do so.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: He will give the same boy a present on his birthday, and buy him a spade and bucket at the seaside, because it is customary to do so, being all the time neither particularly mendacious, nor particularly cruel, nor particularly generous, but simply incapable of ethical judgment or independent action.
next_sentence: Vivisection is customary as part of the routine of preparing lectures in medical schools.

question: Naturally, the poor [MASK] (that is, the average doctor) defends ordinary vaccination frantically, as it means to him the bread of his children.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: century inoculation, by a purely reactionary law making all sorts of vaccination, scientific or not, criminal offences.
next_sentence: To secure the vehement and practically unanimous support of the rank and file of the medical profession for any sort of treatment or operation, all that is necessary is that it can be easily practised by a rather shabbily dressed man in a surgically dirty room in a surgically dirty house without any assistance, and that the materials for it shall cost, say, a penny, and the charge for it to a patient with 100 pounds a year be half-a-crown.

question: Tonsils, vermiform appendices, uvulas, even ovaries are sacrificed because it is the fashion to get them cut out, and because the operations are [MASK] profitable.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: By making doctors tradesmen, we compel them to learn the tricks of trade; consequently we find that the fashions of the year include treatments, operations, and particular drugs, as well as hats, sleeves, ballads, and games.
next_sentence: The psychology of fashion becomes a pathology; for the cases have every air of being genuine: fashions, after all, are only induced epidemics, proving that epidemics can be induced by tradesmen, and therefore by doctors.

question: But we must face that: in such crowded and [MASK] ridden civilizations as ours any orthodoxy is better than laisser-faire.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: And here we come to the danger that terrifies so many of us: the danger of having a hygienic orthodoxy imposed on us.
next_sentence: If our population ever comes to consist exclusively of well-to-do, highly cultivated, and thoroughly instructed free persons in a position to take care of themselves, no doubt they will make short work of a good deal of official regulation that is now of life-and-death necessity to us; but under existing circumstances, I repeat, almost any sort of attention that democracy will stand is better than neglect.

question: Yet [MASK] expect to find vaccines and antitoxins and the like retailed at``popular prices"in private enterprise shops just as they expect to find ounces of tobacco and papers of pins.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: But the precautions necessary to insure that the inoculation shall consist of nothing else but the required germ in the proper state of attenuation are a very different matter from the precautions necessary in the distribution and consumption of beefsteaks.
next_sentence: THE PERILS OF INOCULATION  The trouble does not end with the matter to be inoculated.

question: Between these extremes [MASK] the main body of doctors (also, of course, with a weak and a strong end) who can be trusted to work under regulations with more or less aid from above according to the gravity of the case.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Assuming that doctors are normal men and not magicians (and it is unfortunately very hard to persuade people to admit so much and thereby destroy the romance of doctoring) we may guess that the medical profession, like the other professions, consists of a small percentage of highly gifted persons at one end, and a small percentage of altogether disastrous duffers at the other.
next_sentence: Or, to put it in terms of the cases, there are cases that present no difficulties, and can be dealt with by a nurse or student at one end of the scale, and cases that require watching and handling by the very highest existing skill at the other; whilst between come the great mass of cases which need visits from the doctor of ordinary ability and from the chiefs of the profession in the proportion of, say, seven to none, seven to one, three to one, one to one, or, for a day or two, none to one.

question: But the greatest [MASK] of all on the side of vivisection is the mighty and indeed divine force of curiosity.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: THE TREE OF KNOWLEDGE.
next_sentence: Here we have no decaying tribal instinct which men strive to root out of themselves as they strive to root out the tiger's lust for blood.

question: [MASK] support of vivisection is founded almost wholly on the assurances of the vivisectors that great public benefits may be expected from the practice.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Here, then, is a pretty deadlock.
next_sentence: Not for a moment do I suggest that such a defence would be valid even if proved.

question: Treat the private operator [MASK] as you would treat a private executioner.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors

question: Here then, we have in vivisection, as in all the other [MASK] and instituted cruelties, this anti-climax: that only a negligible percentage of those who practise and consequently defend it get any satisfaction out of it.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: The routine man is in the majority in his profession always: consequently the moment his practice is tracked down to its source in human passion there is a great and quite sincere poohpoohing from himself, from the mass of the profession, and from the mass of the public, which sees that the average doctor is much too commonplace and decent a person to be capable of passionate wickedness of any kind.
next_sentence: As in Mr. Galsworthy's play Justice the useless and detestable torture of solitary imprisonment is shown at its worst without the introduction of a single cruel person into the drama, so it would be possible to represent all the torments of vivisection dramatically without introducing a single vivisector who had not felt sick at his first experience in the laboratory.

question: We all do just as [MASK] things, with even less excuse.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: We must therefore give ourselves no airs of superiority when denouncing the cruelties of vivisection.
next_sentence: But in making that admission we are also making short work of the virtuous airs with which we are sometimes referred to the humanity of the medical profession as a guarantee that vivisection is not abused--much as if our burglars should assure us that they arc too honest to abuse the practice of burgling.

question: The [MASK] was the same; but the prescriptions were different, and so was the advice.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: During the first great epidemic of influenza towards the end of the nineteenth century a London evening paper sent round a journalist-patient to all the great consultants of that day, and published their advice and prescriptions; a proceeding passionately denounced by the medical papers as a breach of confidence of these eminent physicians.
next_sentence: Now a doctor cannot think his own treatment right and at the same time think his colleague right in prescribing a different treatment when the patient is the same.

question: And here we come to the danger that terrifies so many of us: the [MASK] of having a hygienic orthodoxy imposed on us.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Unless the Church works the pretended miracle painfully against the grain, and is continually urged by its dislike of the imposture to strive to make the peasant susceptible to the true reasons for behaving well, the Church will become an instrument of his corruption and an exploiter of his ignorance, and will find itself launched upon that persecution of scientific truth of which all priesthoods are accused and none with more justice than the scientific priesthood.
next_sentence: But we must face that: in such crowded and poverty ridden civilizations as ours any orthodoxy is better than laisser-faire.

question: It was, of course, impossible for any [MASK] of sense and honor to assume divine omniscience by answering this in the affirmative, or indeed pretending to be able to answer it at all.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: The prosecution broke down when the doctor in the witness box was asked whether, if the child had had medical attendance, it would have lived.
next_sentence: And on this the judge had to instruct the jury that they must acquit the prisoner.

question: Every general practitioner is supposed to be capable of the whole range of medical and surgical work at a moment's notice; and the country doctor, who has not a specialist nor a crack consultant at the [MASK] of his telephone, often has to tackle without hesitation cases which no sane practitioner in a town would take in hand without assistance.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Even if they were, things would still not be as bad as in the medical profession; for in it not only is the first-class man set to do third-class work, but, what is much more terrifying, the third-class man is expected to do first-class work.
next_sentence: No doubt this develops the resourcefulness of the country doctor, and makes him a more capable man than his suburban colleague; but it cannot develop the second-class man into a first-class one.

question: It is the nurse who [MASK] the doctor away in private, because every nurse has some particular doctor whom she likes; and she usually assures her patients that all the others are disastrous noodles, and soothes the tedium of the sick-bed by gossip about their blunders.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: The only evidence that can decide a case of malpractice is expert evidence: that is, the evidence of other doctors; and every doctor will allow a colleague to decimate a whole countryside sooner than violate the bond of professional etiquet by giving him away.
next_sentence: She will even give a doctor away for the sake of making the patient believe that she knows more than the doctor.

question: But it holds good over the entire [MASK] of human activity.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Everybody recognizes this in the case of the amatory infatuations of the adolescents who see angels and heroes in obviously (to others) commonplace and even objectionable maidens and youths.
next_sentence: The hardest-headed materialist will become a consulter of table-rappers and slate-writers if he loses a child or a wife so beloved that the desire to revive and communicate with them becomes irresistible.

question: Thieves and assassins understand quite well that there are paths of [MASK], even of the best things, that are barred to all men of honor.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: No highway robber has yet harrowed us with denunciations of the puling moralist who allows his child to suffer all the evils of poverty because certain faddists think it dishonest to garotte an alderman.
next_sentence: Again, has the silliest burglar ever pretended that to put a stop to burglary is to put a stop to industry?

question: All the grossest lies and superstitions which have disgraced the vaccination craze were [MASK] to the doctors by the public.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: At all events, the public, which had been boundlessly credulous about the cow, would not have the horse on any terms; and to this day the law which prescribes Jennerian vaccination is carried out with an anti-Jennerian inoculation because the public would have it so in spite of Jenner.
next_sentence: It was not the doctors who first began to declare that all our old men remember the time when almost every face they saw in the street was horribly pitted with smallpox, and that all this disfigurement has vanished since the introduction of vaccination.

question: Then perform a second [MASK] on persons engaged in mathematical work or machine designing, so as to ascertain the symptoms of cold scientific activity?
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Why not perform a careful series of experiments on persons under the influence of voluptuous ecstasy, so as to ascertain its physiological symptoms?
next_sentence: Then note the symptoms of a vivisector performing a cruel experiment; and compare them with the voluptuary symptoms and the mathematical symptoms?

question: And there is this curious psychological fact to be remembered: a serious illness or a death advertizes the doctor exactly as a hanging advertizes the barrister who defended the person [MASK].
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: The only ones who can claim to be above suspicion are those who are so much sought after that their cured patients are immediately replaced by fresh ones.
next_sentence: Suppose, for example, a royal personage gets something wrong with his throat, or has a pain in his inside.

question: The one lesson that comes out of all our theorizing and [MASK] is that there is only one really scientific progressive method; and that is the method of trial and error.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Attention and activity lead to mistakes as well as to successes; but a life spent in making mistakes is not only more honorable but more useful than a life spent doing nothing.
next_sentence: If you come to that, what is laisser-faire but an orthodoxy?

question: Thus even the layman has to be taught that infallibility is not quite infallible, because there are two qualities of it to be had at two [MASK].
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Yet the two guinea man never thinks that the five shilling man is right: if he did, he would be understood as confessing to an overcharge of one pound seventeen shillings; and on the same ground the five shilling man cannot encourage the notion that the owner of the sixpenny surgery round the corner is quite up to his mark.
next_sentence: But there is no agreement even in the same rank at the same price.

question: The notion that therapeutics or hygiene or surgery is any more or less scientific than [MASK] or cleaning boots is entertained only by people to whom a man of science is still a magician who can cure diseases, transmute metals, and enable us to live for ever.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: But I may remind those who confusedly imagine that the medical problem is also the scientific problem, that all problems are finally scientific problems.
next_sentence: It may still be necessary for some time to come to practise on popular credulity, popular love and dread of the marvellous, and popular idolatry, to induce the poor to comply with the sanitary regulations they are too ignorant to understand.

question: It is simply unscientific to allege or believe that doctors do not under existing circumstances perform unnecessary operations and [MASK] and prolong lucrative illnesses.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: To offer me a doctor as my judge, and then weight his decision with a bribe of a large sum of money and a virtual guarantee that if he makes a mistake it can never be proved against him, is to go wildly beyond the ascertained strain which human nature will bear.
next_sentence: The only ones who can claim to be above suspicion are those who are so much sought after that their cured patients are immediately replaced by fresh ones.

question: He dare not stop making hay while the sun shines; for it may set at any [MASK].
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Though he is exceptionally exposed to infection, and has to face all weathers at all hours of the night and day, often not enjoying a complete night's rest for a week, the money stops coming in the moment he stops going out; and therefore illness has special terrors for him, and success no certain permanence.
next_sentence: Men do not resist pressure of this intensity.

question: Science becomes dangerous only when it [MASK] that it has reached its goal.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: We call them by different names: Immunization or Radiology or what not; but the dreams which lure us into the adventures from which we learn are always at bottom the same.
next_sentence: What is wrong with priests and popes is that instead of being apostles and saints, they are nothing but empirics who say "I know" instead of "I am learning," and pray for credulity and inertia as wise men pray for scepticism and activity.

question: And every hypochondriacal rich lady or gentleman who can be persuaded that he or she is a lifelong invalid means anything from fifty to five hundred pounds a [MASK] for the doctor.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: But here, as at the other end of the scale, the right advice is neither agreeable nor practicable.
next_sentence: Operations enable a surgeon to earn similar sums in a couple of hours; and if the surgeon also keeps a nursing home, he may make considerable profits at the same time by running what is the most expensive kind of hotel.

question: When they recover (and they mostly do) the doctor gets the credit of [MASK] them.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: When men die of disease they are said to die from natural causes.
next_sentence: In surgery all operations are recorded as successful if the patient can be got out of the hospital or nursing home alive, though the subsequent history of the case may be such as would make an honest surgeon vow never to recommend or perform the operation again.

question: If machines were as cheap as frogs, engineers would not only be taught the anatomy of machines and the functions of their parts: they would also have machines misused and wrecked before them so that they might learn as much as possible by [MASK] their eyes, and as little as possible by using their brains and imaginations.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Such clumsy and lazy ways of teaching are based on the cheapness of frogs and rabbits.
next_sentence: Thus we have, as part of the routine of teaching, a routine of vivisection which soon produces complete indifference to it on the part even of those who are naturally humane.

question: But on the other hand his expenses are [MASK].
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: He always has plenty of genuine cases which can afford genuine treatment; and these provide him with enough sincere scientific professional work to save him from the ignorance, obsolescence, and atrophy of scientific conscience into which his poorer colleagues sink.
next_sentence: Even as a bachelor, he must, at London west end rates, make over a thousand a year before he can afford even to insure his life.

question: The net gain of ten per thousand is credited to the method, and made the excuse for [MASK] more of it.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Everything is put to the credit of the particular method employed, although it may quite possibly be raising the death rate by five per thousand whilst the attention incidental to it is reducing the death rate fifteen per thousand.
next_sentence: STEALING CREDIT FROM CIVILIZATION  There is yet another way in which specifics which have no merits at all, either direct or incidental, may be brought into high repute by statistics.

question: Juries seldom notice facts; and they have been [MASK] to regard any doubts of the omniscience and omnipotence of doctors as blasphemy.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Usually it is impossible to persuade the jury that these facts are facts.
next_sentence: Even the fact that doctors themselves die of the very diseases they profess to cure passes unnoticed.

question: We are, as a matter of fact, a cruel nation; and our habit of disguising our vices by [MASK] polite names to the offences we are determined to commit does not, unfortunately for my own comfort, impose on me.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: But in making that admission we are also making short work of the virtuous airs with which we are sometimes referred to the humanity of the medical profession as a guarantee that vivisection is not abused--much as if our burglars should assure us that they arc too honest to abuse the practice of burgling.
next_sentence: Vivisectors can hardly pretend to be better than the classes from which they are drawn, or those above them; and if these classes are capable of sacrificing animals in various cruel ways under cover of sport, fashion, education, discipline, and even, when the cruel sacrifices are human sacrifices, of political economy, it is idle for the vivisector to pretend that he is incapable of practising cruelty for pleasure or profit or both under the cloak of science.

question: But here, as at the other end of the [MASK], the right advice is neither agreeable nor practicable.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: The proper advice for most of their ailments is typified in Abernethy's "Live on sixpence a day and earn it."
next_sentence: And every hypochondriacal rich lady or gentleman who can be persuaded that he or she is a lifelong invalid means anything from fifty to five hundred pounds a year for the doctor.

question: Treat persons who profess to be able to cure disease as you treat fortune [MASK].
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors

question: Now vagrants have [MASK] power of resisting any disease: their death rate and their case-mortality rate is always high relatively to that of respectable folk.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: In the case of a prophylactic enforced by law, this illusion is intensified grotesquely, because only vagrants can evade it.
next_sentence: Nothing is easier, therefore, than to prove that compliance with any public regulation produces the most gratifying results.

question: This, you thought, [MASK] what a sovereign healer mummy was.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: You took a pinch of the dust of a dead Egyptian in a pint of the hottest water you could bear to drink; and it did you a great deal of good.
next_sentence: But if you had tried the control experiment of taking the hot water without the mummy, you might have found the effect exactly the same, and that any hot drink would have done as well.

question: But the moment the controversy [MASK] embittered, the recriminations bandied between the opposed parties bring us face-to-face with some very ugly truths.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Indecent, because there is an accepted convention to repudiate cruelty; and vivisection is only tolerated by the law on condition that, like judicial torture, it shall be done as mercifully as the nature of the practice allows.
next_sentence: On one occasion I was invited to speak at a large Anti-Vivisection meeting in the Queen's Hall in London.

question: There may be a doctor here and there who in dealing with the statistics of disease has taken at least the first step towards sanity by grasping the fact that as an attack of even the commonest disease is an exceptional event, apparently over-whelming statistical evidence in favor of any prophylactic can be produced by persuading the [MASK] that everybody caught the disease formerly.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: STATISTICAL ILLUSIONS  Public ignorance of the laws of evidence and of statistics can hardly be exaggerated.
next_sentence: Thus if a disease is one which normally attacks fifteen per cent of the population, and if the effect of a prophylactic is actually to increase the proportion to twenty per cent, the publication of this figure of twenty per cent will convince the public that the prophylactic has reduced the percentage by eighty per cent instead of increasing it by five, because the public, left to itself and to the old gentlemen who are always ready to remember, on every possible subject, that things used to be much worse than they are now (such old gentlemen greatly outnumber the laudatores tempori acti), will assume that the former percentage was about 100.

question: On the other [MASK] cancer and madness have increased (statistically) to an appalling extent.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Had such a suggestion been adopted, the theory would have been triumphantly confirmed; for as a matter of fact, typhus fever has disappeared.
next_sentence: The opponents of the little finger theory would therefore be pretty sure to allege that the amputations were spreading cancer and lunacy.

question: Do not try to [MASK] for ever.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
next_sentence: You will not succeed.

question: His first experiment was on two [MASK] patients.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: But he did not begin with himself.
next_sentence: On receiving a message from the hospital to the effect that these two martyrs to therapeutic science had all but expired in convulsions, he experimented on a rabbit, which instantly dropped dead.

question: If a guinea pig may be sacrificed for the sake of the very little that can be learnt from it, shall not a man be sacrificed for the sake of the great [MASK] that can be learnt from him?
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Once grant the ethics of the vivisectionists and you not only sanction the experiment on the human subject, but make it the first duty of the vivisector.
next_sentence: At all events, he is sacrificed, as this typical case shows.

question: Now it cannot be too often repeated that when an operation is once performed, [MASK] can ever prove that it was unnecessary.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Thus amazing case makes it possible to say, with some prospect of being believed, that there is in the classes who can afford to pay for fashionable operations a sprinkling of persons so incapable of appreciating the relative importance of preserving their bodily integrity, (including the capacity for parentage) and the pleasure of talking about themselves and hearing themselves talked about as the heroes and heroines of sensational operations, that they tempt surgeons to operate on them not only with large fees, but with personal solicitation.
next_sentence: If I refuse to allow my leg to be amputated, its mortification and my death may prove that I was wrong; but if I let the leg go, nobody can ever prove that it would not have mortified had I been obstinate.

question: Thus it is easy to prove that the wearing of tall hats and the carrying of umbrellas enlarges the chest, prolongs life, and confers comparative immunity from disease; for the statistics show that the [MASK] which use these articles are bigger, healthier, and live longer than the class which never dreams of possessing such things.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Or, to take another common instance, comparisons which are really comparisons between two social classes with different standards of nutrition and education are palmed off as comparisons between the results of a certain medical treatment and its neglect.
next_sentence: It does not take much perspicacity to see that what really makes this difference is not the tall hat and the umbrella, but the wealth and nourishment of which they are evidence, and that a gold watch or membership of a club in Pall Mall might be proved in the same way to have the like sovereign virtues.

question: It may even [MASK] that the selfishness of an artist may be a benefit to the public by enabling him to concentrate himself on their gratification with a recklessness of every other consideration that makes him highly dangerous to those about him.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: An actor, a painter, a composer, an author, may be as selfish as he likes without reproach from the public if only his art is superb; and he cannot fulfil his condition without sufficient effort and sacrifice to make him feel noble and martyred in spite of his selfishness.
next_sentence: In sacrificing others to himself he is sacrificing them to the public he gratifies; and the public is quite content with that arrangement.

question: It may be deserved or it may not: there it is at all events, and the doctors who have not realized this are living in a [MASK]'s paradise.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: That is the character the medical profession has got just now.
next_sentence: As to the humor and conscience of doctors, they have as much as any other class of men, no more and no less.

question: No knowledge is finally impossible of human attainment; for even though it may be beyond our present capacity, the needed capacity is not [MASK].
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: CRUELTY FOR ITS OWN SAKE  It will now, I hope, be clear why the attack on vivisection is not an attack on the right to knowledge: why, indeed, those who have the deepest conviction of the sacredness of that right are the leaders of the attack.
next_sentence: Consequently no method of investigation is the only method; and no law forbidding any particular method can cut us off from the knowledge we hope to gain by it.

question: Now a doctor cannot think his own treatment right and at the same time think his colleague [MASK] in prescribing a different treatment when the patient is the same.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: The case was the same; but the prescriptions were different, and so was the advice.
next_sentence: Anyone who has ever known doctors well enough to hear medical shop talked without reserve knows that they are full of stories about each other's blunders and errors, and that the theory of their omniscience and omnipotence no more holds good among themselves than it did with Moliere and Napoleon.

question: The notion that the man who does dreadful things is superhuman, and that therefore he can also do wonderful things either as ruler, avenger, healer, or what not, is by no means confined to [MASK].
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Vivisection helps the doctor to rule us as Peter ruled the Russians.
next_sentence: Just as the manifold wickednesses and stupidities of our criminal code are supported, not by any general comprehension of law or study of jurisprudence, not even by simple vindictiveness, but by the superstition that a calamity of any sort must be expiated by a human sacrifice; so the wickednesses and stupidities of our medicine men are rooted in superstitions that have no more to do with science than the traditional ceremony of christening an ironclad has to do with the effectiveness of its armament.

question: In this case the doctor was devoted enough to carry his experiments to the point of running [MASK] risks, and actually making himself very uncomfortable.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: He was one of those doctors who are able to command public sympathy by saying, quite truly, that when they discovered that the proposed treatment was dangerous, they experimented thenceforth on themselves.
next_sentence: But he did not begin with himself.

question: Not that this can exonerate any vivisector from suspicion of enjoying his work (or her work: a good [MASK] of the vivisection in medical schools is done by women).
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: As in Mr. Galsworthy's play Justice the useless and detestable torture of solitary imprisonment is shown at its worst without the introduction of a single cruel person into the drama, so it would be possible to represent all the torments of vivisection dramatically without introducing a single vivisector who had not felt sick at his first experience in the laboratory.
next_sentence: In every autobiography which records a real experience of school or prison life, we find that here and there among the routineers there is to be found the genuine amateur, the orgiastic flogging schoolmaster or the nagging warder, who has sought out a cruel profession for the sake of its cruelty.

question: The only knowledge we lose by forbidding cruelty is knowledge at first hand of [MASK] itself, which is precisely the knowledge humane people wish to be spared.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Consequently no method of investigation is the only method; and no law forbidding any particular method can cut us off from the knowledge we hope to gain by it.
next_sentence: But the question remains: Do we all really wish to be spared that knowledge?

question: An unpunctual man is always in a hurry; but it does not [MASK] that hurry is the cause of unpunctuality: on the contrary, what is the matter with the patient is sloth.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: It was also evident that the characteristic microbe of a disease might be a symptom instead of a cause.
next_sentence: When Florence Nightingale said bluntly that if you overcrowded your soldiers in dirty quarters there would be an outbreak of smallpox among them, she was snubbed as an ignorant female who did not know that smallpox can be produced only by the importation of its specific microbe.

question: To boot, there is the occasional windfall of an epidemic, with its panic and [MASK] for revaccination.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: The medical profession, consisting for the most part of very poor men struggling to keep up appearances beyond their means, find themselves threatened with the extinction of a considerable part of their incomes: a part, too, that is easily and regularly earned, since it is independent of disease, and brings every person born into the nation, healthy or not, to the doctors.
next_sentence: Under such circumstances, vaccination would be defended desperately were it twice as dirty, dangerous, and unscientific in method as it actually is.

question: Doctoring is not even the art of keeping people in health (no doctor seems able to advise you what to eat any better than his grandmother or the nearest [MASK]): it is the art of curing illnesses.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Doctoring is an art, not a science: any layman who is interested in science sufficiently to take in one of the scientific journals and follow the literature of the scientific movement, knows more about it than those doctors (probably a large majority) who are not interested in it, and practise only to earn their bread.
next_sentence: It does happen exceptionally that a practising doctor makes a contribution to science (my play describes a very notable one); but it happens much oftener that he draws disastrous conclusions from his clinical experience because he has no conception of scientific method, and believes, like any rustic, that the handling of evidence and statistics needs no expertness.

question: Doctors are no more proof against such [MASK] than other men.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: The Imperialist who regards the conquest of England by a foreign power as the worst of political misfortunes believes that the conquest of a foreign power by England would be a boon to the conquered.
next_sentence: Can anyone then doubt that under existing conditions a great deal of unnecessary and mischievous operating is bound to go on, and that patients are encouraged to imagine that modern surgery and anesthesia have made operations much less serious matters than they really are?

question: He employed incendiaries to set it on fire; and he played the harp in scientific raptures whilst it was [MASK].
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Nero argued in the same way about Rome.
next_sentence: I am so far of Nero's way of thinking that I have often said, when consulted by despairing sanitary reformers, that what London needs to make her healthy is an earthquake.

question: The dramatic possibilities of this discovery and [MASK] will be found in my play.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: And he invented a technique for ascertaining in which phase the patient happened to be at any given moment.
next_sentence: But it is one thing to invent a technique: it is quite another to persuade the medical profession to acquire it.

question: As a good many people countenance vivisection because they fear that if the experiments are not made on rabbits they will be made on themselves, it is worth noting that in this case, where both rabbits and men were equally available, the men, being, of [MASK], enormously more instructive, and costing nothing, were experimented on first.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: It was then, and not until then, that he began to experiment on himself, with the germicide modified in the direction indicated by the experiments made on the two patients and the rabbit.
next_sentence: Once grant the ethics of the vivisectionists and you not only sanction the experiment on the human subject, but make it the first duty of the vivisector.

question: Unlike the man of business, whose managers, clerks, warehousemen and laborers keep his business [MASK] whilst he is in bed or in his club, the doctor cannot earn a farthing by deputy.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Above all, the income which provides for these outgoings stops the moment he himself stops working.
next_sentence: Though he is exceptionally exposed to infection, and has to face all weathers at all hours of the night and day, often not enjoying a complete night's rest for a week, the money stops coming in the moment he stops going out; and therefore illness has special terrors for him, and success no certain permanence.

question: We shall see later on that the claim that has arisen in this [MASK] for the unconditioned pursuit of knowledge is as idle as all dreams of unconditioned activity; but none the less the right to knowledge must be regarded as a fundamental human right.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: When Gray said "Where ignorance is bliss, 'tis folly to be wise," he forgot that it is godlike to be wise; and since nobody wants bliss particularly, or could stand more than a very brief taste of it if it were attainable, and since everybody, by the deepest law of the Life Force, desires to be godlike, it is stupid, and indeed blasphemous and despairing, to hope that the thirst for knowledge will either diminish or consent to be subordinated to any other end whatsoever.
next_sentence: The fact that men of science have had to fight so hard to secure its recognition, and are still so vigorously persecuted when they discover anything that is not quite palatable to vulgar people, makes them sorely jealous for that right; and when they hear a popular outcry for the suppression of a method of research which has an air of being scientific, their first instinct is to rally to the defence of that method without further consideration, with the result that they sometimes, as in the case of vivisection, presently find themselves fighting on a false issue.

question: Even trained statisticians often [MASK] to appreciate the extent to which statistics are vitiated by the unrecorded assumptions of their interpreters.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: But to the public every Pasteur patient who did not die was miraculously saved from an agonizing death by the beneficent white magic of that most trusty of all wizards, the man of science.
next_sentence: Their attention is too much occupied with the cruder tricks of those who make a corrupt use of statistics for advertizing purposes.

question: Everything is put to the credit of the particular method employed, although it may quite possibly be raising the [MASK] rate by five per thousand whilst the attention incidental to it is reducing the death rate fifteen per thousand.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: Simple and obvious as this is, nobody seems as yet to discount the effect of substituting attention for neglect in drawing conclusions from health statistics.
next_sentence: The net gain of ten per thousand is credited to the method, and made the excuse for enforcing more of it.

question: The hardest-headed materialist will become a consulter of table-rappers and slate-writers if he loses a child or a wife so beloved that the desire to revive and [MASK] with them becomes irresistible.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: But it holds good over the entire field of human activity.
next_sentence: The cobbler believes that there is nothing like leather.

question: We think no more of the condition of a doctor attending a case than of the [MASK] of a fireman at a fire.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: He may be hungry, weary, sleepy, run down by several successive nights disturbed by that instrument of torture, the night bell; but who ever thinks of this in the face of sudden sickness or accident?
next_sentence: In other occupations night-work is specially recognized and provided for.

question: The [MASK] among us wore hats and cloaks and head-dresses obtained by wholesale massacres, ruthless trappings, callous extermination of our fellow creatures.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: I found myself on the platform with fox hunters, tame stag hunters, men and women whose calendar was divided, not by pay days and quarter days, but by seasons for killing animals for sport: the fox, the hare, the otter, the partridge and the rest having each its appointed date for slaughter.
next_sentence: We insisted on our butchers supplying us with white veal, and were large and constant consumers of pate de foie gras; both comestibles being obtained by revolting methods.

question: To ascertain the right moment a laboratory and a staff of experts are [MASK].
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: The discoveries of Sir Almroth Wright have shown that the appalling results which led to the hasty dropping in 1894 of Koch's tuberculin were not accidents, but perfectly orderly and inevitable phenomena following the injection of dangerously strong "vaccines" at the wrong moment, and reinforcing the disease instead of stimulating the resistance to it.
next_sentence: The general practitioner, having no such laboratory and no such experience, has always chanced it, and insisted, when he was unlucky, that the results were not due to the inoculation, but to some other cause: a favorite and not very tactful one being the drunkenness or licentiousness of the patient.

question: No doubt they [MASK] the analysis as far as they could afford to carry it for the money.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: I do not suggest that the analysts were dishonest.
next_sentence: No doubt also they could afford to carry it far enough to be of some use.

question: The general [MASK], having no such laboratory and no such experience, has always chanced it, and insisted, when he was unlucky, that the results were not due to the inoculation, but to some other cause: a favorite and not very tactful one being the drunkenness or licentiousness of the patient.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: To ascertain the right moment a laboratory and a staff of experts are needed.
next_sentence: But though a few doctors have now learnt the danger of inoculating without any reference to the patient's "opsonic index" at the moment of inoculation, and though those other doctors who are denouncing the danger as imaginary and opsonin as a craze or a fad, obviously do so because it involves an operation which they have neither the means nor the knowledge to perform, there is still no grasp of the economic change in the situation.

question: That distinction is the line that separates the [MASK] from the man in the old classification.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: THE OLD LINE BETWEEN MAN AND BEAST  But there is still a distinction to be clung to by those who dare not tell themselves the truth about the medical profession because they are so helplessly dependent on it when death threatens the household.
next_sentence: Granted, they will plead, that we are all cruel; yet the tame-stag-hunter does not hunt men; and the sportsman who lets a leash of greyhounds loose on a hare would be horrified at the thought of letting them loose on a human child.

question: But it is poor and [MASK] to be protected cheaply.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: It dreads disease and desires to be protected against it.
next_sentence: Scientific measures are too hard to understand, too costly, too clearly tending towards a rise in the rates and more public interference with the insanitary, because insufficiently financed, private house.

question: If we did, no man's neck would be safe and no man's [MASK] stable.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: But we take good care not to make the hangman and the housebreaker the judges of that.
next_sentence: But we do make the doctor the judge, and fine him anything from sixpence to several hundred guineas if he decides in our favor.

question: But instead of proposing such an investigation, our vivisectors offer us all the pious protestations and all the [MASK] recriminations that any common unscientific mortal offers when he is accused of unworthy conduct.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: They might open a line of investigation which would finally make, for instance, the ascertainment of the guilt or innocence of an accused person a much exacter process than the very fallible methods of our criminal courts.
next_sentence: ROUTINE  Yet most vivisectors would probably come triumphant out of such a series of experiments, because vivisection is now a routine, like butchering or hanging or flogging; and many of the men who practise it do so only because it has been established as part of the profession they have adopted.

question: That is the predicament the doctor finds himself in when he has to defend himself against a [MASK] of malpractice by a plea of ignorance and fallibility.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: But if apothecaries and motor car makers habitually advertized elixir of life and perpetual motion, and succeeded in creating a strong general belief that they could supply it, they would find themselves in an awkward position if they were indicted for allowing a customer to die, or for burning a chauffeur by putting petrol into his car.
next_sentence: His plea is received with flat credulity; and he gets little sympathy, even from laymen who know, because he has brought the incredulity on himself.

question: It was not until an agitation had been conducted for many years by laymen, including quacks and faddists of all kinds, that the public was sufficiently impressed to make it possible for the doctors to open their minds and their mouths on the [MASK] of fresh air, cold water, temperance, and the rest of the new fashions in hygiene.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: That is why all the changes come from the laity.
next_sentence: At present the tables have been turned on many old prejudices.

question: In vain do the sentimental champions of vivisection declare themselves the most humane of men, inflicting suffering only to relieve it, scrupulous in the use of anesthetics, and void of all [MASK] except the passion of pity for a disease-ridden world.
source_info: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors by Shaw, Bernhard
title: The Doctor's Dilemma: Preface on Doctors
prev_sentence: It may be as wounding to the personal vanity of the vivisector as Darwin's Origin of Species was to the people who could not bear to think that they were cousins to the monkeys (remember Goldsmith's anger when he was told that he could not move his upper jaw); but science has to consider only the truth of the hypothesis, and not whether conceited people will like it or not.
next_sentence: The really scientific investigator answers that the question cannot be settled by hysterical protestations, and that if the vivisectionist rejects deductive reasoning, he had better clear his character by his own favorite method of experiment.
